chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Undescended testes
chapter.summary: Covers the primary care management of suspected unilateral and bilateral undescended testes.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From birth onwards (Male).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage suspected undescended testes?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Management of suspected undescended testes is dependent on the location and presence of the testes following clinical assessment.

  • If there is a suspected disorder of sexual development and/or bilateral undescended testes are identified at birth:
    • Ensure urgent referral to a paediatrician within 24 hours has been arranged (ideally within a tertiary children's unit with a specialist disorders of sexual development service), as the child may need urgent endocrine or genetic investigation.
    • If a disorder of sexual development is excluded and the testes are not present in the scrotum by 4–5 months of age, ensure the child has been referred to paediatric surgery or urology, to be seen by 6 months of age.
  • If there are suspected bilateral undescended testes at 6–8 weeks of age:
    • Arrange urgent referral to a paediatrician to be seen within 2 weeks.
  • If there is a suspected unilateral undescended testis:
    • At birth — re-examine the infant at 6–8 weeks of age. If both testes are normally descended, no further action is required.
    • At 6–8 weeks of age — re-examine the infant at 4–5 months of age.
    • At 4–5 months (corrected for gestational age), if the testis remains undescended, arrange referral to paediatric surgery or urology for specialist management depending on local referral pathways, to be seen by 6 months of age.
      • If both testes are normally descended, no further action is required.
      • If there is any uncertainty in differentiating between a possible undescended testis and retractile testis, arrange referral for clarification of the diagnosis.
      • If both testes are in the scrotum, but one or both are retractile, advise the parents/carers that annual follow up and re-examination is needed until after puberty, as there is a significant risk of ascending testis.
  • If an older boy or man presents with suspected unilateral or bilateral undescended testes:
    • Arrange referral to paediatric surgery, paediatric urology, or urology, depending on the age of the person and clinical judgement.
    • Advise boys and young men with a history of undescended testis to perform regular testicular self-examination during and after puberty, owing to the increased risk of developing testicular cancer. See the CKS topic on Scrotal pain and swelling for more information.
  • Offer parents/carers advice on sources of information and support, such as:
    • The British Association of Urological Surgeons patient leaflet on Missing testicle.
    • The patient leaflet Undescended testicles available on the www.patient.info website.
    • The NHS patient leaflet Undescended testicles.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Specialist management
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Specialist management of unilateral or bilateral undescended testes is determined by the location and presence of the testes.

  • Surgical treatment
    • Surgery is usually the preferred treatment of undescended testes as it is the most effective and reliable method of bringing testes into the scrotum.
      • The palpable testis is usually treated surgically by orchidopexy (the freeing of an undescended testis and implanting it into the scrotum) using an inguinal approach. In less severe cases, scrotal orchidopexy may be an option.
        • Surgical success rates of 88–100% are cited, with low rates of recurrence, and a risk of postoperative testicular atrophy of less than 1%. Other rare complications include vas deferens injury, wound infection or dehiscence, and haematoma.
      • For a non-palpable testis, examination under anaesthesia with inguinal exploration and diagnostic laparoscopy may be needed to locate an intra-abdominal testis and perform subsequent orchidopexy or orchidectomy (removal of the testis).
        • If the testis is palpable within the inguinal canal or at the deep inguinal ring, a single-stage operation may be successful.
        • Alternatively, a two-stage procedure may be needed, involving intra-abdominal high ligation of the testicular vessels, and then mobilisation of the testis into the scrotum.
      • The European Association of Urology (EAU) recommends that orchidolysis and orchidopexy are ideally performed before 12 months of age, and by 18 months of age. The British Association of Paediatric Surgeons (BAPS) recommends that if orchidopexy is indicated, it should be performed around 12 months of age.
      • Surgical management of ascending testis may involve orchidopexy before puberty. In post-pubertal boys there is an increased risk of malignancy in the undescended testis, so orchidectomy may be considered if the contralateral testis is normal in a scrotal position.
  • Hormone treatment
    • There is no consensus in the literature on the benefits of hormone treatment for undescended testes.
      • In general, hormone therapy has been found to be ineffective and is not recommended.
      • The EAU guidelines note weak evidence for a possible role for hormone treatment for bilateral undescended testes to preserve fertility potential.

[BAPS, 2015; Radmayr, 2016; Hutson, 2017; Cho, 2019; EAU, 2019; Yeap, 2019]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the management of suspected undescended testes are based on the British Association of Paediatric Surgeons (BAPS) consensus commissioning guide Paediatric orchidopexy for undescended testis [BAPS, 2015], the European Association of Urology (EAU) guidelines Paediatric Urology [EAU, 2019], the American Urological Association (AUA) guidelines Evaluation and treatment of cryptorchidism [Kolon, 2014], a European consensus document Undescended testes: a consensus on management [Ritzen, 2008], the Public Health England (PHE) guidance Newborn and infant physical examination (NIPE) screening programme handbook [PHE, 2019], and expert opinion in review articles on undescended testes [Docimo, 2000; Radmayr, 2016; Hutson, 2017; Cho, 2019; Yeap, 2019].

Management of a suspected disorder of sexual development
  • The recommendation to ensure urgent referral has been arranged within 24 hours of the examination is largely based on the PHE guidance, which notes that this is needed to rule out metabolic and intersex conditions [PHE, 2019]. The recommendation to refer to a specialist tertiary centre if available is based on the expert opinion of a previous external reviewer of this CKS topic.
  • This approach is supported by the BAPS consensus commissioning guide that notes that if a diagnosis of suspected undescended testis is associated with penile abnormalities, referral to a specialist tertiary paediatric surgical unit is needed [BAPS, 2015].
  • This is further supported by the AUA guidelines [Kolon, 2014] and expert opinion in review articles [Radmayr, 2016; Hutson, 2017; Cho, 2019]. In particular, specialist investigations include immediate karyotyping, blood tests, and pelvic ultrasound to rule out possible virilized cases of congenital adrenal hyperplasia [Docimo, 2000; Radmayr, 2016]. This is important as congenital adrenal hyperplasia may be associated with life-threatening electrolyte disturbances [Cho, 2019; Yeap, 2019].
  • The recommendation on management if a disorder of sexual development is excluded but the testes remain undescended is extrapolated from the PHE guidance [PHE, 2019], and is also pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Arranging urgent paediatric referral if suspected bilateral undescended testes at 6–8 weeks
  • This recommendation is based on the PHE guidance on infant physical examination [PHE, 2019].
Management of suspected unilateral undescended testis
  • The recommendations on timings of examinations and management are largely based on the PHE guidance on infant physical examination [PHE, 2019], the BAPS consensus commissioning guide [BAPS, 2015], and expert opinion in review articles [Radmayr, 2016; Hutson, 2017; Cho, 2019; Yeap, 2019].
    • The BAPS consensus commissioning guide recommends that if an undescended testis is identified in primary care, the infant needs referral to a paediatric surgeon or urologist with appropriate skills and experience. It also recommends that orchidopexy surgery should occur at around 12 months of age, as spontaneous descent of an undescended testis does not occur after 3 months of age and germ cell loss is preventable with early surgery. It notes that early surgery is safe and reproducible.
    • The PHE guidance notes that early diagnosis and intervention improves fertility, reduces the risk of torsion, and may help earlier identification of testicular cancer.
    • Expert opinion in a review article notes that spontaneous testicular descent is unlikely to occur after 6 months of age, there is a progressive loss of germ cells at 12–18 months of age, and prompt orchidopexy is a significant factor for fertility preservation [Radmayr, 2016].
    • This approach is supported by expert opinion in a review article, which notes the optimal timing for surgery is 6–12 months of age, with the aim to prevent or reverse abnormal germ cell development and reduce the risk of future infertility and development of testicular cancer. Timing of surgery after 12 months leads to a poorer prognosis for future fertility [Hutson, 2017].
    • Expert opinion in additional review articles note that timely referral and surgical correction may improve fertility and reduce the malignancy rate associated with undescended testes [Cho, 2019; Yeap, 2019]. One review article recommends referral at 3–6 months for unilateral undescended testis, and orchidopexy between 6–12 months of age [Yeap, 2019].
  • The recommendation to arrange annual follow up and re-examination for boys with retractile testes is based on the BAPS consensus commissioning guide [BAPS, 2015], the EAU guidelines [EAU, 2019], the AUA guidelines [Kolon, 2014], and expert opinion in a review article [Hutson, 2017].
    • The BAPS consensus commissioning guide notes that in older boys retractile testes need follow up as there is a 3–20% risk of permanent ascent.
    • This approach is supported by the EAU guidelines that do not recommend medical or surgical treatment for retractile testes, but advise annual monitoring is needed until puberty as up to one-third of cases can ascend and become undescended over time.
    • The AUA guidelines also recommend annual monitoring of boys with retractile testes to check for secondary ascent.
    • Expert opinion in a review article notes that 'acquired' undescended testis (ascending testis) may occur later in childhood, and typically needs surgical correction between 5–10 years of age [Hutson, 2017].
Management of older boys and men
  • The recommendation to arrange appropriate referral depending on clinical judgement is extrapolated from expert opinion in a European consensus document [Ritzen, 2008], and is also based on the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic. It is also pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
  • The recommendation to advise regular self-examination for testicular cancer is based on expert opinion in review articles [Radmayr, 2016; Cho, 2019].
Offering advice on sources of information and support
  • This recommendation is based on the BAPS consensus commissioning guide [BAPS, 2015] and the AUA guidelines, which recommend providing information and advice on the long-term implications of undescended testes [Kolon, 2014].
